sen.j: 円如（えんにょ、延徳元年（1489年） - 永正18年8月20日_(旧暦)（1521年9月20日））は、戦国時代_(日本)の浄土真宗の僧侶。
sen.e: Ennyo (1489-September 20, 1521) was the monk of Jodo Shinshu Sect (Pure Land Buddhist Sect) during the Warring States Period (Japan).
Ennyo (1489 - September 20, 1521) was a monk of the Jodo Shinshu (Pure Land Buddhist) sect during the Warring States period (Japan).
Ennyo (1489 - September 30, 1521) was a monk of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦にしました。

sen.e: His imina (real personal name) was Koyu.
His imina (real personal name) was Koyu.
His imina (personal name) was Koyu.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 本願寺9世法主・実如の次男、同10世法主・証如の父。
sen.e: He was the second son of the ninth head of Hongan-ji Temple, and the father of tenth head of the temple, Shoni.
He was the second son of the ninth head of Hongan-ji Temple, and was the father of Shoni, the tenth head of the temple.
He was the second son of the ninth head of Hongan-ji Temple, Jitsunyo, and was the father of Shonyo, the tenth head of the temple.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせ補足しました。

sen.j: 母は高倉永継の娘・如祐。
sen.e: His mother was Nyoyu, who was the daughter of Nagatsugu TAKAKURA.
His mother was Nyoyu, who was the daughter of Nagatsugu TAKAKURA.
His mother was Nyoyu, who was the daughter of Nagatsugu TAKAKURA.

sen.j: 父に先立って没したために歴代本願寺法主には加えられていない。
sen.e: Since he died before his father, he was not assigned to be the successive Hossu (the head of a Buddhist sect) of Hongan-ji Temple.
Because his death preceded that of his father, he wasn't assigned to be the successive Hossu (head of a Buddhist sect) of Hongan-ji Temple.
Because his death preceded that of his father, he wasn't assigned to be the successive Hossu (head of a Buddhist sect) of Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 山科区にて生まれ、12歳の時に兄・照如の死を受けて得度して本願寺法嗣に定められる。
sen.e: He was born in Yamashina Ward and entered Hongan-ji Temple at the age of twelve as a disciple due to the death of his older brother, Shonyo (照如).
He was born in Yamashina Ward and entered Hongan-ji Temple at 12 years of age as a disciple, due to the death of his older brother Shonyo (照如).

He was born in Yamashina Ward, entered the Buddhist priesthood at 12 years of age, and assumed as the position of hoshi (successor of principle) of Hongan-ji Temple, after the death of his older brother Shonyo (照如).

sen.j: 高齢の父に代わって教団の実務を行う。
sen.e: He carried out activities of the religious society in place of his aged father.
He carried out the activities of the religious society in place of his aged father.
He carried out the activities of the religious society in place of his aged father.

sen.j: 北陸門徒に対し一揆の禁止をはじめとする3か条の戒めを発布したり、本願寺の一族を一門衆（嫡男）と一家衆（次男以下）に分ける一門一家制を設けたり、蓮如の文書の中から80通を選んで5帖に編集し御文とよんで宗門信条の基本とするなどの教団改革を行い、戦国期の本願寺体制の基礎を築いたが、33歳の若さで没した。
sen.e: He distributed the Three Clauses of Warning to ban the uprising of disciples in Hokuriku (northern Japan), created Ichimonikka System (one disciple, one family act) that divided the Hongan-ji Temple clan into Ichimonshu (one disciple group) (legal son) and ikkashu (one family group) (below second son), re-established the religious group by collecting eighty letters from the documents of Renka and edited into five books to make it into the basics of Shumonshinjo (the religious group codes), and built the basic platform of Hongan-ji Temple during the Sengoku Period, but died at the young age of thirty-three.

He distributed the Three Clauses of Warning to ban the uprising of disciples in Hokuriku (northern Japan), created the Ichimonikka System (one disciple, one family act) that divided the Hongan-ji Temple clan into Ichimonshu (one disciple group) (legal son) and ikkashu (one family group) (below second son), re-established the religious group by collecting 80 letters from the documents of Renka and edited it into five books to create the basics of Shumonshinjo (the religious group codes), and built the basic platform of Hongan-ji Temple during the Sengoku period; however, he died at just 33 years of age.

He distributed the Three Clauses of Warning to ban the uprising of followers in Hokuriku (northern Japan), created the Ichimon-Ikke System that divided the Hongan-ji families into Ichimonshu (clansman) (for legitimate son) and ikkeshu (the same linage people as the Hongan-ji Temple) (for second son and younger), re-established the religious group by collecting 80 letters from the documents of Rennyo and edited it into five books called Ofumi to create the basics of Shumonshinjo (the religious group codes), and built the basic platform of Hongan-ji Temple during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States); however, he died at just 33 years of age.
